page.title: 12Farming in 1985
page.content: Farming is mainly arable with some fat cattle and sheep. Chief crops grown are grass, wheat, barley and oilseed rape, with its vivid yellow flowers. Its oil is used in margarine. EEC guaranteed prices have led to more grain and rape being grown; oats are now grown less. Harvesting is done by combines, which both thresh the grain and throw out the straw. Contractors who take machines from farm to farm are often employed for harvesting. Commonly the stubble and surplus straw are burnt. This is said to kill pests and diseases but the smoke can cause a nuisance and hedges and small animals may be damaged. Use of pesticides and herbicides has increased grain yields and hedges have been grubbed out to aid in use of machinery. Attempts to drill seed without ploughing have not been wholly successful.
